sanskrit_verse:
संधिं च विग्रहं चैव यानमासनमेव च ।
द्वैधीभावं संश्रयं च षड्गुणांश्चिन्तयेत्सदा ॥ ७.१६०॥
transliteration:
saṃdhiṃ ca vigrahaṃ caiva yānam āsanam eva ca |
dvaidhībhāvaṃ saṃśrayaṃ ca ṣaḍguṇāṃś cintayet sadā || 7.160 ||
sph_interpretive_translation: One must always deliberate upon conciliation, conflict, movement, stillness, duality, dependence, and the sixfold qualities—these constitute the full spectrum of relational dynamics within consciousness.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority resides in the capacity to discern relational dynamics
Causation arises from conscious choice among dualities
Capacity-based responsibility requires contemplation of all relational modes
Restoration logic operates through integration of conflicting forces
Consciousness alignment emerges via sustained reflection on relational completeness
executable_legal_axioms: IF a dispute involves relational fragmentation THEN initiate contemplative review of saṃdhi-vigraha-yāna-āsana-dvaita-śraya-ṣaḍguṇa spectrum
WHEN evaluating intent, MAP action to one or more of six relational modes BEFORE determining misalignment
ENSURE judicial process includes reflective phase where all six relational dimensions are consciously considered by adjudicator
ASSIGN corrective pathway based on which relational mode was neglected or distorted
supreme_court_application: At the Supreme Court level, this verse mandates that adjudicators must not proceed with judgment until the full relational matrix—conciliation through sixfold qualities—is reviewed. Responsibility is measured not by outcome alone but by whether the actor engaged fully with the relational field.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that distortion in any of the six relational modes creates anupūrvaśaḥ leading to misalignment. Nyaya demands restoration through reintegration of neglected modes. No punitive response is required; completion of relational awareness restores natural order.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate reflective dialogue between parties covering each of the six relational modes
Assign completion practices ensuring responsible party engages with previously avoided relational aspects
Realign consciousness through guided contemplation of dvaita-advaita spectrum
Establish ongoing mentorship to ensure mature navigation of future relational decisions
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of Dharma. This law restores relational integrity through consciousness-centered deliberation. There is no punishment—only realignment. Reality responds to completeness, not control. Consciousness is the ultimate judge.
